title: Automatic creation of multiple bundles
body:
This is a feature request or a workflow question.

I have a hyper modular application. Its entry point is currently a file that imports all the features:

```
require('./feature-a');
require('./feature-b');
require('./feature-c');
```

I would like to know of a way to split this entry point into separate bundles. **The motive here is performance:** make each feature be available as soon as possible.

**Wrong solution 1:** I could simply create a bundle directly from each feature, but the problem is that they have shared dependencies; doing so would include the dependency in each file.

**Wrong solution 2:** Create a bundle for each, plus a bundle with common dependencies (with `factor-bundle`) and load it first. This sort of works, but the scripts can't be loaded with `async` so if `common.js` is large, a smaller `feature-d` still has to wait for it to load, even if it doesn't depend on it.

**Ideal solution:** create x bundles from the first file and make internal requires work like AMD. Instead of having a single, heavy `common.js`, the first 1-2 levels of dependencies are transformed into AMD requires and bundled into smart bundles:

e.g. if only `feature-b` requires `jquery` and `lodash`, make a single bundle with all the three.
e.g. if `feature-a` and `feature-c` require `kew` and `raf`, either bundle them together, or create a `a-c-common.js` file.

---

I know this sounds complex, but maybe someone already came up with a better solution. For now I've only manually created 2-4 bundles that have 0 shared dependencies (or they do… and load them multiple times)

title: browserify-11.0.1: source maps don't work for 'main' file when browserify is called with dot argument...
body:
Hi to all:

browserify-11.0.1: errors in application 'main file' map to bundle file when browserify is called with dot argument, but not when 'main file' is used as argument...

If I call:

`$ browserify -d . > bundle.js`

errors in my main file - app.js (according to package.json):

```
{
  "name": "browserify-source-map-issue",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "main": "app.js",
  "dependencies": {
    "browserify": "^11.0.1"
  }
}
```

map to 'bundle.js' file, see ![casea](http://i.imgur.com/3JMDzdc.png).

If instead I call it:

`$ browserify -d app.js > bundle.js`

errors in my main file work as expected ![caseb](http://i.imgur.com/v9s9lcB.png)

this is 100% reproducible.

app.js - only 1 line: 

```
nonexistantfunction();
```

I created this github repo for convenience: https://github.com/acamari/browserify-issue

To reproduce: `$ npm install; browserify -d . > bundle.js; chrome index.html`

Thanks to all.

title: browserify Truck Factor
body:
As part of my PhD research on code authorship, we calculated the Truck Factor (TF) of some popular GitHub repositories.

As you probably know, the [Truck (or Bus) Factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bus_factor) designates the minimal number of developers that have to be hit by a truck (or quit) before a project is incapacitated. In our work, we consider that a system is in trouble if more than 50% of its files become orphan (i.e., without a main author).

More details on our work in this preprint: https://peerj.com/preprints/1233

We calculated the TF for **browserify** and obtained a value of **1**.

The developer responsible for this TF is:

James Halliday - author of 85% of the files 

To validate our results, we would like to ask **browserify** developers the following three brief questions:

(a) Do you agree that the listed developer is the main developer of **browserify**?

(b) Do you agree that **browserify** will be in trouble if the listed developer leave the project (e.g., if he wins in the lottery, to be less morbid)?

(c) Does **browserify** have some characteristics that would attenuate the loss of the listed developer (e.g., detailed documentation)?

Thanks in advance for your collaboration,

Guilherme Avelino
PhD Student
Applied Software Engineering Group (ASERG)
UFMG, Brazil
http://aserg.labsoft.dcc.ufmg.br/

title: Duplicate sub-dependencies are included when bundling
body:
Hi,

we're managing a big web app and wondered why our final app bundle is so big. So to see what is actually required by browserify I did:

`browserify -e js/app.js --list > webapp-dependencies.txt`

I found that there are instances where sub-dependencies are bundled into the application multiple times:

```
/node_modules/react-router-bootstrap/node_modules/classnames/index.js -v ^2.0.0
/node_modules/react-bootstrap/node_modules/classnames/index.js - ^2.0.0
/node_modules/classnames/index.js - v 1.2.2
```

So since both react-router-bootstrap and react-bootstrap could (and maybe do) use the same version of classnames.js, I'm wondering why they're not bundled as one dependency.

I assume this is a bug, right?

title: Streams3 all the things!
body:
There are lots of browserify dependencies (and `brfs` dependencies) that are still using old versions of `readable-stream`. We could make the install faster (and perhaps bundle sizes smaller), if we updated everything to `^2.0.0`.

```
$ npm outdated
readable-stream                1.0.33  1.0.33    2.0.2  brfs > static-module > readable-stream
readable-stream                1.1.13  1.1.13    2.0.2  browserify > labeled-stream-splicer > stream-splicer > readable-wrap > readable-stream
readable-stream                1.1.13  1.1.13    2.0.2  browserify > duplexer2 > readable-stream
readable-stream                1.1.13  1.1.13    2.0.2  browserify > labeled-stream-splicer > stream-splicer > readable-stream
readable-stream                1.1.13  1.1.13    2.0.2  browserify > read-only-stream > readable-stream
readable-stream                1.1.13  1.1.13    2.0.2  brfs > static-module > duplexer2 > readable-stream
readable-stream                1.1.13  1.1.13    2.0.2  browserify > read-only-stream > readable-wrap > readable-stream
```

title: Browserify does not allow the requiring of standard JSON.
body:
Hi Everyone,

I'm using grunt-browserify (and by extension browserify), and have discovered something rather peculiar:

I have a json file, called common.json. If I try to require it like this (valid JSON):

```
{
  "name": "Ari is the King"
}
```

It throw an error, Unexpected token at 2:8.

If I make it like this (invalid JSON): 

```
{
  name: "Ari is the King"
}
```

Everything works well.

I think this is a bug, or is it some kind of intended behavior?

I **_think**_ it's caused by browserify prepending module.exports onto the file, and for some reason not allowing quoted keys in JS.

Thanks!

title: b.add() API change since 10.1.1 ?
body:
Since `10.1.1`, b.add() will not resolve to a node module.

For example:
##### Before 10.1.1:

I can b.add('superagent') to bundle a node module in a project.
##### After 10.1.1:

I will get "Cannot find module"
##### To reproduce it.

npm init test // init a project
npm install superagent --save // simply add a node module
npm install browserify // install browserify

Set up a `./test.js` in the project:

```
var browserify = require('browserify');
var b = browserify();
b.add('superagent');
b.bundle(function(err, buf) {
    if (err) return console.log(err):
    console.log(buf.toStrinig())
});
```

In command line, `node ./test.js` will callback error 'Cannot find module'.
But, if we change to browserify@10.1.0

npm install browserify@10.1.0

We'll get a bundled code.

title: option to pass in built-ins
body:
love browserify, but would love to use it in many other places than the browser, e.g. chromeapp, react-native. For that, I need to be able to set my own builtins - e.g. it may be hard/impossible for the browser to support fs, dgram, net, but react-native and chromeapp absolutely can:

[react-native-level-fs](https://github.com/tradle/react-native-level-fs)
[react-native-udp](https://github.com/tradle/react-native-udp)

this is not to say they should use those particular shims, but that the dev should be able to choose which shims to use

related: 

[support for alternative "browser" field, e.g. "chromeapp"](https://github.com/defunctzombie/node-browser-resolve/pull/57)

[react-native packager built-ins issue](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/issues/1871#issuecomment-122127488)

Edit: if this sounds like a good idea, i can try to hack it up

title: absolute path in output file
body: If I bundle a script, that requires [jquery.transit](https://www.npmjs.com/package/jquery.transit) and [jquery](https://www.npmjs.com/package/jquery) with `browserify({fullPaths: false}).bundle(myFile)` my output file contains an absolute path: `<absolute path to my project>/node_modules/jQuery/dist/jquery.js`. It only contains the absolute path if I require both modules.

title: Replace http-browserify with stream-http
body:
stream-http uses new-style streams to provide true streaming or
pseudo-streaming in as many browsers as possible.

It uses the new fetch api with native browser streams where available
(currently only chrome supports this combination) and various
browser-specific xhr extensions to make binary-safe streaming
work where possible.

It is tested and working with at least basic functionality
back to IE8.

title: symlink change in 10.2.5 is breaking our builds
body:
Problem: 
1. We have two modules, `app` and `shared`
2. `shared` is symlinked into `app`
3. Both `app` and `shared` use a module `foo`, which is installed in `app/node_modules/foo` (but not `shared/node_modules`)
4. Now `shared` can't find `foo`

As far as I can tell, node.js doesn't have this problem.

title: Different casing on require loads module twice
body:
When requiring a module, changing the capitalization of the module can trick browserify into loading the same module twice. I'm unsure of if this is due to using a case-insensitive filesystem, or some other reason.

title: Browserify resolves the same file multiple times
Node api created by the foundation
body:
The node.js foundation has opened a repo to create a working group around the JSApi
https://github.com/nodejs/api
this is a good opportunity to improve the alignment  between the browserify implementation and server node by sharing tests and making the core spec more in tune with running node in non server environments.
hope some folks here find this useful

title: Why there isn't flag --bundle-external-only?
body:
There is a flag `--no-bundle-external` which restricts bundle requires to local files. Why there isn't flag `--bundle-external-only`? It would be very convenient when splitting code into `app.js` and `vendor.js` for example.

For now you have to know the list of external dependencies and call `.exclude(...)` when building `app.js` and `.require(...)` when building `vendor.js`.

title: streams3
body:
To upgrade to streams3 (readable-stream ^2) we'll need to use the next major version of stream-browserify, which has already been published. Unfortunately this upgrade causes some strange cyclic dependency behavior in the browserify crypto tests (test/crypto.js and test/crypto_ig.js): https://github.com/substack/stream-browserify/pull/9#issuecomment-115370040

```
TypeError: evalmachine.<anonymous>:15118
          ctor.prototype = Object.create(superCtor.prototype, {
                                                  ^
      Cannot read property 'prototype' of undefined
```

Strangely, I don't get this error invoking browserify directly:

```
$ browserify <(echo "console.log(require('crypto').createHash('sha256').update('whatever').digest('hex'))") | node
85738f8f9a7f1b04b5329c590ebcb9e425925c6d0984089c43a022de4f19c281
$ browserify <(echo "console.log(require('crypto').createHash('sha256').update('whatever').digest('hex'))") | browser-run
85738f8f9a7f1b04b5329c590ebcb9e425925c6d0984089c43a022de4f19c281
^C
```

title: Make source map output more configurable
body:
I think it makes sense to make the source map output more configurable and I want to talk about how to expose that. I know @zertosh  has already [expressed support for exposing `sourceRoot`](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/681#issuecomment-103554709).

I think some kind of namespacing makes sense for clarity and consistency. For example, while it might not be awful to expose `sourceRoot` via an `opts.sourceRoot` option, it makes little sense to expose `file` via an `opts.file` option, and I think it'd be ugly to end up with something inconsistent like `opts.sourceRoot` and `opts.sourceMapFile`.

Here are what seem like the most sensible ideas to me:
1. `sourceMap` prefix, e.g. `sourceMapSourceRoot`, `sourceMapFile`.
   Pros: Pretty self explanatory, simple to implement.
   Cons: Fairly verbose.
2. `sm` prefix, e.g. `smSourceRoot`, `smFile`.
   Pros: Simple to implement, compact.
   Cons: Less self-explanatory, but easily explained via documentation.
3. `opts.sourceMap` hash, e.g. `sourceMap: {sourceRoot: '...', file: '...'}` (overwrite all defaults), and deep property merging (selectively overwrite defaults), e.g. `'sourceMap.sourceRoot': '...'`.
   Pros: All source map config contained in single object instead of a bunch of separate properties, ability to overwrite all defaults just by passing an object as `opts.sourceMap`.
   Cons: More complicated implementation, need to quote keys to selectively overwrite properties, fairly verbose.

See also: #1304, #1233.

I'm also interested in the idea of allowing the user to pass in a function to manipulate the source map before it's written.

title: Error: Cannot find module './object' : require('./standalonebundle.js')
body:
(I am new to node.)
### Webapp
1. I generated a `standalonebundle.js`, which works fine in the browser via the `script` tag, via:

```
browserify src/index.js -g aliasify -s myHook -d -p [minifyify --no-map] -o build/standalonebundle.js
```
1. I copied it into another module, next to the source code in `./src`
2. I did 'require('./standalonebundle.js')' in `./src`
3. Starting my web-app (which gets browserified itself), I get the error:

```
events.js:85
      throw er; // Unhandled 'error' event

Error: Cannot find module './object' from '[path]/src
```
### Local test
1. I created a test.js with 'require('./standalonebundle.js')'
2. I get the error:

```
node test.js 

[path]my-browserified-0.1.18.js:2
typeof navigator||!/MSIE [1-9]\./.test(navigator.userAgent)){var t=e.document,
                                                                    ^
TypeError: Cannot read property 'document' of undefined
    at [path]my-browserified-0.1.18.js:2:232
```

The documentation states that it should be possible to include standalone bundles via browserify. I suppose I am doing something wrong.

(The reason I am not doing a usual `require('mymodule')` is that, `mymodule` wraps legacy code and aliasifies globally `fs` with `my-fs`. I don't want calling modules to be responsible for using aliasify globally on `mymodule`. Because a calling module should not be responsible for the inner workings of the module it calls.)

title: ENOENT, open 'buffer' using --no-browser-field
body:
(I am new to node and tried to solve this by going through the issues.)
### Setup

```
external-legacy-module  <-   my-wrapper-module    <-    my-application
                              standalone bundle.js       browserify pulling the 
                              by browserify              standalone bundle.js
```
### Context

I am trying to browserify a module (which wraps legacy code of an external bundle) as a standalone bundle. This standalone bundle works fine in the browser, including it via the `script` tag.

But I want to use it as a regular node module, too. Calling it from an application, using browserify, I figured that I need to provide the standalone bundle using the `browser field`. But this means that running browserify in the wrapper module itself needs to ignore the `browser field`. This results in an error.
### Config

Terminal (wrapper module):

```
browserify src/index.js --no-browser-field -g aliasify -s myHook -d -p [minifyify --no-map] -o build/bundle.js
Error: ENOENT, open 'buffer'
    at Error (native)
```

package.json (wrapper module):

```
"main": "./src/index.js",
[...]
"browser": "./build/bundle.js",
  "browserify": {
    "transform": [
      "aliasify"
    ]
  },
  "aliasify": {
    "aliases": {
      "fs": "./src/my-fs.js"
    }
  }
```

title: browserify can't deal with sub modules with files that don't end with .js
body:
For example:

``` bash
cd tmpDir
npm init
npm install browserify mocha
echo 'require("mocha")' > index.js
./node_modules/.bin/browserify index.js
```

I get an error like this:

```
Error: Cannot find module './runnable' from '/Users/Moshe/tmp/node_modules/mocha'
    at /Users/Moshe/tmp/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:55:21
    at load (/Users/Moshe/tmp/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:69:43)
    at onex (/Users/Moshe/tmp/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:92:31)
    at /Users/Moshe/tmp/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:22:47
    at FSReqWrap.oncomplete (fs.js:78:15)
```

If I change `'../runnable'` to `'../runnable.js'` then the next time I run it I get an error about the next file that doesn't have a `.js` in it

using iojs 1.8.1

title: Seal bundle environment by default
body:
Originally posed as a comment in #1073, but this really deserves a separate issue.

The `--standalone` flag has the benefit of redefining `define`, `module`, and `exports` to prevent leakage. This is critical when scripts are being deployed to 3rd party sites. 

_**Side Note:** Looks like documentation is lacking on this point._

Sealing the bundle environment (as accomplished by `--standalone`) should be possible without the requirement that the script be enclosed in a UMD wrapper.

I suggest:
1. Seal the environment by default
2. Rename the `--standalone` option to `--umd`

See https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/1073#issuecomment-99015865 for a more detailed description of the issue.

title: using a bundle as an external does not automatically expose the libs
body:
The docs say that `bundle.external(anotherBundle)` will exclude the `anotherBundle` libs from `bundle`. This is great but unlike something like `factor-bundle`, this does not seem to properly expose the libs to `bundle`.

For example:

**main.js**

```
var $ = require('jquery');
```

**common.js**

```
var $ = require('jquery');
```

**build.js**

```
var commonBundle = browserify({entries: 'common.js'});
var mainBundle = browserify({entries: 'main.js'});
mainBundle.external(commonBundle);
```

This still requires the following extra code to expose jquery back to the `mainBundle`:

```
commonBundle.require('jquery');
```

I may be misunderstanding something but it is surprising this doesn't work right now. The extra requires make this not quite automatic, and in my case the `common.js` contains a fair number of dependencies I want to be exposed in the `main.js` so doing it manually is not ideal.

title: Modules specified in --entry from the command line are being included in the wrong order
body:
This is odd: when using the Browserify command-line tool and passing in multiple entry points, the entry points are not executed in the order supplied. But the order is not random: the _first_ script you supply is always run _last_, and all other scripts are run in the order that you passed them.

Naturally, I think it should preserve the order that you specify entirely, to ensure the correct ordering of side-effects in your entry scripts.

Here's a micro-repro:

```
$ npm install browserify
$ echo 'console.log("hello")' > a.js
$ echo 'console.log("world")' > b.js
$ echo 'console.log("!")' > c.js
$ node_modules/.bin/browserify -e a.js b.js c.js -o app.js
$ node app.js
```

Expected output:

```
hello
world
!
```

Actual output:

```
world
!
hello
```

Tested at Browserify `10.2.3`.

title: Error when using `exposeAll` with external
body:
If I do something like the following:

``` js
browserify({ debug: true, exposeAll: true })
    .external('_env/messages')
    .add('./src/my/entry.js')
```

This is because on [this line](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/10.2.3/index.js#L413) `row.deps['_env/messages']` is `false`, which throws this error:

```
path.js:146
      throw new TypeError('Arguments to path.resolve must be strings');
      ^
TypeError: Arguments to path.resolve must be strings
    at Object.win32.resolve (path.js:146:13)
    at Object.win32.relative (path.js:270:14)
    at ...\node_modules\browserify\index.js:413:44
```

If I add `if (!row.deps[key]) return;` just above the path() call, then the bundle builds without error. I'm not 100% sure that this is the correct fix, so I posted an issue instead of a PR.

title: Globs
body:
Browserify doesn't seem to handle globs very well. There are many shell/platform combinations and it would be pretty neat if it could be decoupled from the environment it is running in by relying on environment to parse and match files.

On Windows, Git Bash, I'm trying to ignore all files under a specific module (`**/foo/**/*.js`). In the [resolve function](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L461), the `file` variable looks like this:

```
c:\Users\user\Documents\example\node_modules\foo\module.js
```

The [ex variable](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L476) subsequently looks like this: 

```
/node_modules\foo\module.js
```

And the entry in the [self._ignore](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L483) looks like this:

```
node_modules/foo/module.js
```

Which obviously doesn't match with `indexOf`. Removing the hardcoded slash and changing back slashes to forward slashes fixes it:

``` diff
- var ex = '/' + path.relative(basedir, file);
+ var ex = path.relative(basedir, file).replace(/\\/g, '/');
```

But that's probably just the solution for Windows. A more generic approach is needed here..

Source maps broken in 10.2.0
body:
Looks like update browser-pack to ^5.0.0 broke source maps management by [exorcist](https://github.com/thlorenz/exorcist).

**file.js**:

```
console.log("It works!");
```

```
$ npm list browserify exorcist
├── browserify@10.1.3 
├── exorcist@0.3.0
$ `npm bin`/browserify --debug file.js | `npm bin`/exorcist bundle.js > bundle.map
$ echo $?
0
```

But after upgrade browserify to 10.2.0 exorcist doesn't understand source map generated by browserify,

```
$ `npm bin`/browserify --debug file.js | `npm bin`/exorcist bundle.js > bundle.map
The code that you piped into exorcist contains no source map!
Therefore it was piped through as is and no external map file generated.
```

Source file bundled as,

```
(function e(t,n,r){function s(o,u){if(!n[o]){if(!t[o]){var a=typeof require=="function"&&require;if(!u&&a)return a(o,!0);if(i)return i(o,!0);var f=new Error("Cannot find module '"+o+"'");throw f.code="MODULE_NOT_FOUND",f}var l=n[o]={exports:{}};t[o][0].call(l.exports,function(e){var n=t[o][1][e];return s(n?n:e)},l,l.exports,e,t,n,r)}return n[o].exports}var i=typeof require=="function"&&require;for(var o=0;o<r.length;o++)s(r[o]);return s})({1:[function(require,module,exports){
console.log("It works!");

},{}]},{},[1])
//# sourceMappingURL=data:application/json;charset:utf-8;base64,
```

So `//# sourceMappingURL...` contains in bundle, but couldn't be recognized by exorcist.

title: deps-sort causing stream buffer hwm to be reached
Fix globals transform noParse path matcher
body:
- Fix globals transform noParse path matcher
  - Fixes passing in a function. The logic to call the function is there, but if you passed one in, `path.resolve` would throw because it wasn't a string.
  - Fixes resolving from the `basedir` - not assuming it's the cwd.
  - Optimizes a bit by moving `no` and `absno` into the closure so they're only built once per `b.bundle()`.
  - Adds some tests for this.
- Add test for "noParse"
  - Adds a test for the only way `noParse` for deps works - an array of full paths.

(related to https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/1256)

title: Implement the "noParse" matcher via mdeps "parseFilter"
body:
A proposal based on the discussion in https://github.com/substack/module-deps/pull/54#issuecomment-100236976. Depends on https://github.com/substack/module-deps/pull/87. **don't merge this - the package.json is point to my module-deps branch for this**

Currently the logic for determining whether to parse for deps or not [lives](https://github.com/substack/module-deps/blob/e0e85fa49b564400c7517fc5ba892cf431d53405/index.js#L426-L432) in module-deps. Browserify passes an array of _absolute paths_  to module-deps, and module-deps does a straight `indexOf` against it. A couple of things feel off about this:
1. The pattern matching for exclude, ignore, and the globals transform are each different than noparse and among themselves.
   - This PR begins to address this by isolating the globals transform's file matcher into a `fileFilter` function (idc about the name) for use by a new `parseFilter` available in module-deps.
   - With this logic isolated, we can apply it to exclude and ignore.
2. module-deps doesn't have logic for any kind of path matching - it delegates to "filters".
   - The approach proposed (`parseFilter`) follows in the footsteps of `postFilter`, `filter` and `packageFilter`.

Things that "break":
- It's undocumented but you can currently do `b.require('thing', {noparse: true});` - that wouldn't work anymore.
- module-deps would lose the ability to noparse via the CLI - but that's also undocumented. If this is important, we could implement it in it's `cmd.js`.

Follow ups:
- `fileFilter`, mostly taken from the globals transform is broken - PR coming soon.
- `noParse` doesn't have any tests. About half of the ones here fail against master (bc of new functionality). I'll make a separate PR for the passing ones, so this change doesn't introduce currently unknown regressions.

@jmm @terinjokes 

@substack <-- I don't know if you like being tagged on these things or not

title: Optimization: Add syntax check cache
body:
This PR introduces a caching system for the syntax check. It's a big optimization for repeat builds (think watchify). I had proposed this first in https://github.com/substack/node-syntax-error/pull/9, but substack suggested that it was better implemented here.

I went with a per instance cache instead of a global cache (though it could very safely be one) because I don't want to set the precedent that it's ok for Browserify to be stateful.
